questions.text: In the POP-Q system of uterine prolapse classification, how many fixed points are there?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 6

Explanation: 

  • POP-Q is Pelvic Organ Prolapse – Quantification System. 
  • The hymen acts as the fixed point of reference. 
  • There are 6 defined fixed points for measurement in this system
    • Anterior: Aa, Ba, C
    • Posterior: Ap, Bp, D
  • Three other landmarks are described: 
    • Genital hiatus (gh)
    • Total vaginal length (tvl)
    • Perineal body (pb)
  • Each of these 3 measurements is measured in cm above or proximal to the hymen (negative) or below/ distal to the hymen (positive) with the plane of the hymen as zero (0)

 

Educational Objective: 

  • POP-Q is Pelvic Organ Prolapse – Quantification System. 
  • The hymen acts as the fixed point of reference. 
  • There are 6 defined fixed points for measurement in this system
    • Anterior: Aa, Ba, C
    • Posterior: Ap, Bp, D
  • Three other landmarks are described: 
    • Genital hiatus (gh)
    • Total vaginal length (tvl)
    • Perineal body (pb)
  • Each of these 3 measurements is measured in cm above or proximal to the hymen (negative) or below/ distal to the hymen (positive) with the plane of the hymen as zero (0)

Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology – 16th  EDITION pg- 1610-11( e book)

choices.text: External anal sphincter

questions.text: The deepest part of the perineal body if cut /damaged can lead to rectocele, cystocele and uterine prolapse. This is due to damage of which muscle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pubococcygeus

Weakness of the pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus muscles cause the levator plate to sag and cause prolapse.

Other Options

  • Option A and B: Bulbocavernosus and ISchiocavernosus damage can lead to sexual dysfunction as they are responsible for clitoral orgasm
  • Option D: External anal sphincter damage can lead to anal incontinence

Educational Objective:

  • Weakness of the pubococcygeus and iliococcygeus muscles cause the levator plate to sag and cause prolapse.

Ref: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology – 16th EDITION,( e-book) pg- 1616, 1642

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman complains of constipation and difficulty having bowel movements. She states that she often needs to use her fingers to push her vagina backward to achieve a bowel movement. Her history is otherwise unremarkable. On examination, the lower part of the posterior vaginal wall is seen to prolapse out. The cervix or the bladder does not descend down on bearing. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Posterior colporrhaphy

 

  • This woman has symptoms of a rectocele, which is a posterior vaginal defect.
  • Because the support structure to the rectum is defective, the rectum is impinging into the vagina.
  • The surgical repair in this instance is a posterior colporrhaphy consisting of incision of the vaginal mucosa posteriorly, identification of the edges of the endopelvic fascia, and surgical repair of these edges that have separated.
  • The uterus and bladder are in their place and hence their repair is not required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysterectomy: This is done in women who have a uterine descent and family completed. Since here the primary pathology is defect in the posterior vaginal wall, repair of the posterior wall is sufficient. always avoid unnecessary hysterectomy  

 

Option B. Anterior colporraphy: This is the repair done for cystocele 

 

Option D. Resection and repair of enterocele: This can be done by various techniques like a McCalls culdoplasty or a Moscovitz reapir and is done to correct an enterocele (herniation of small bowel into the posterior vagina

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Anterior colporrhaphy is the surgical procedure to correct a cystocele (descent of bladder into the anterior vaginal wall)
  • Posterior colporrhaphy is the surgical procedure to correct a rectocele (descent of rectum into the posterior vaginal wall)

 

Ref: Page 1093, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 30y G5P4L4 lady with 10 weeks of pregnancy, with third-degree uterine prolapse, is treated with?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ring pessary

  • Ring pessary is the treatment of choice in patients with pregnancy and prolapse. It is required usually till the early 2nd trimeter of gestation, after which there is generally spontaneous correction of prolapse.
  • Ring pessary is also indicated in:
    • Prolapse with patients unfit for surgery
    • Treating a decubitus ulcer

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Cervicopexy is plicating the cervix and is indicated in young nulliparous prolapse (hysteropexy) but it is contraindicated during pregnancy and immediately in the postpartum period. It can only be done after the involution of the uterus is over.
  • Option B: Cervical cerclage is for an incompetent os.
  • Option D: Vaginal packing will help in the presence of a decbitus ulcer and not in a pregnant patient with prolapse

Educational Objective:

  • Ring pessary is the treatment of choice in patients with pregnancy and prolapse. It is required usually till the early 2nd trimeter of gestation, after which there is generally spontaneous correction of prolapse.
  • If a patient with uterine prolapse presents in pregnancy, surgery is NOT done and considered only after the puerperium

 

 

ReF: Page no 539, Williams Gynecology  3rd edition

questions.text: A 65y woman presents with a vaginal mass. She underwent an abdominal hysterectomy 10 years earlier. On examination, she was found to have a vaginal vault prolapse. All the following are possible maangement options except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Colposuspension

 

  • Colposuspension (described by Burch) is a surgery for stress urinary incontinence and not for vault prolapse.
  • The best surgery (gold standard) for vault prolapse is abdominal sacrocolpopexy.

* Abdominal sacrocolpopexy is the gold standard management option for vault prolapse

Educational Objective: 

  • The best surgery (gold standard) for vault prolapse is abdominal sacrocolpopexy. This can be done by laparotomy or by laparoscopy or by robotic surgery

 

Ref: Page no 1098, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Vaginal polyp
Uterine prolapse
Uterine inversion
Vaginal fibroid

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the given figure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Uterine prolapse

  • Pelvic organ prolapse
    Pelvic organ prolapse, including cystocele, rectocele, and enterocele, are vaginal hernias commonly seen in multiparous women. 
    • Cystocele is a hernia of the bladder wall into the vagina, causing a soft anterior fullness. Cystocele may be accompanied by urethrocele
    • Rectocele is a herniation of the terminal rectum into the posterior vagina, causing a collapsible pouch-like fullness.
    • Enterocele is a vaginal vault hernia containing small intestine, usually in the posterior vagina and resulting from a deepening of the pouch of Douglas.
    • Uterocervical prolapse: Prolapse of the uterus into the vaginal canal

In the image shown, the uterus can be identified by the presence of the cervix

Other Options:

Option A: Vaginal polyp: This appears as a soft tissue protuberance; originating from the vagina. It is better made out on a speculum exam. Also the cervix will not be seen as is seen in the above picture of a prolapse

Option B: Uterine inversion: Here the uterus turns inside out. So again the cervix will not be seen. Also the endometrium will be seen which appears has a reddish velvety appearance

Option C: Vaginal fibroid: Here a well circumscribed firm structure will be seen and felt. Again the cervix will not be seen as there is no uterine descent.

Educational Objective: 

  • A uterine prolapse can be identified by the presence of the cervix

 

Ref: Page no 539, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A lady underwent vaginal hysterectomy for Carcinoma cervix. Following the surgery after her urethral catheter was removed, she complained of leaking of urine. Methylene blue dye was instilled in her bladder through her urethra, and she was given oral Phenazopyridine dye. After some time, her pads were checked and it showed yellow staining at the top most pad, while the middle or bottom pads were unstained. She is likely to have?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ureterovaginal fistula

 

Explanation

 

  • In this patient methylene blue dye was instilled in bladder and she was given oral phenazopyridine dye. Pad showed yellow staining at the top portion, but not the middle or bottom portions. She is likely to have Ureterovaginal fistula.
  • The urine, which is being brought by ureters is yellow due to oral intake of phenazopyridine which stains the urine yellow.
  • The methylene blue which is in the bladder is not staining the swab as there is no Vesico or urethero-vaginal fistula.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Urge Incontinence: This is a type of urinary incontinence in adults, which involves sudden compelling urges to void and results in involuntary leakage of urine

 

Option C. Neurogenic bladder: This presents as urgency, frequency or even as continuois urinary incontience. However as there is no fistula, on the 3 swab test, there will be no staining or wettingof the swabs

 

Option D. Urinary tract infection: This will present as frequency and burning micturition. It can also present as fever, flank pain and constitutional symptoms in pyelonephritis. 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

 

Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: A 55 years old multigravida with history of frequently micturating due to coughing laughing & sneezing. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Stress incontinence

EXPLANATION

Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI)

  • The common type of stress incontinence is associated with cystocele and genital pro­lapse when the woman voids a small quantity of urine involuntarily while sneezing, coughing or laughing. The condition also develops during pregnancy and soon after delivery.
  • Cause 
  1. Bladder neck descent (70-80%) – loss of integrity of fibro muscular tissue that support bladder neck & urethra.
  2. Intrinsic sphincter defect

 

  • C/F – no urgency, frequency, noturia or dysuria
  • Tests
  1. Bonney’s test – insert 2 fingers in paraurethral region àbladder neck lifted à SUI get corrected. (Indicate bladder neck descent)
  2. Marchetti test –similar to Bonney’s test – uses Allis forceps.
  3. Q tip test – sterile cotton swab introduced into the level of bladder neck – pt asked to strain. Elevation >30° indicates urethra hypermobility.

 

 

Other Options

  • Option A: Urge incontinence: This is seen in overactive bladder where there is an urgent need to void and the patient may leak urine before reaching the toilet
  • Option C: Neurogenic bladder: This presents as overflow incontinence i.e. the patient will not feel the sensation to void and hence will leak
  • Option D: UTI: This will present as frequency and burning and very rarely as incontinence but this is temporary

Educational Objective: 

: Page no 607, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm.
The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm.
The fistula is related to pelvic radiation
The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks

questions.text: Spontaneous healing of a genitourinary fistula via continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter is more likely to happen in which of the following settings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. The fistula is small, 2 to 3 mm

Explanation

  • Occasionally, genitourinary fistulas may spontaneously close during continuous bladder drainage using an indwelling urinary catheter.
  • Urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization, especially if the fistula is small (2- to 3-mm diameter).

Other Options: 

  • Option A: The fistula is large, greater than 2 cm: Large fistulas are unlikely to heal spontaneusly
  • Option C: The fistula is related to pelvic radiation: Post Radiotherapy fistulas heal poorly
  • Option D: The catheter is left in place for a minimum of 8 weeks: If the fistula is small, urinary fistulas close spontaneously after 2 to 8 weeks of transurethral catheterization

Educational Objective:

Ref: Page 608, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: “Three-swab” or tampon test with diluted solution of methylene blue instilled (retrograde) into the bladder

questions.text: Which of the following diagnostic tools or techniques would help identify a ureterovaginal fistula?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intravenous pyelogram

Explanation

  • For ureterovaginal fistulas,the investigation of choice is a CT urography as CT urography will clearly show extravasaton from the ureter and the site of injury. 
  • However since this is not there in the option and the closest option to a CT urography is an intravenus pyelogram which will also demonstrate extravasation of contrast from ureter with mild to moderate hydro-uretero nephrosis. 
  •  Also it is important to remember that the presence of contrast in the vagina gives a typical cup and saucer sign in vesico-vaginal fistula.

Other Options

  • Option A: Cystourethroscopy: This is for diagnosis of vesico vaginal fistula or urethro vaginal fistula 
  • Option C: Voiding cystourethrogram: It is not useful in uretero vaginal fistulas. Evaluation of a uro genital fistula is incomplete without a functional study like a IV or CT urography as 12% of VVF patietns have concomitant uretro vaginal fistulas
  • Option D: 3 swab test: It is not a confirmatory test. It is a clinical test when a uro-genital fistulas is suspected

Educational Objective: 

  • The investigation of choice to diagnose a uretero vaginal fistula is a CT urography
  • Other investigationa are
    • Cystoscopy + Retrograde Pyelography
    • Intra venous pyelogram
    • MR urography

Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Positive pressure urethrography

questions.text: Your patient, who underwent hysterectomy 3 months ago, complains of urine leakage from her vagina. You suspect she has developed a vesicovaginal fistula. Which of the following radiologic tests is the most appropriate to order in her evaluation?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. CT urography

Explanation

  • Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT – urography) scanning in the excretory phase has become the preferred diagnostic test for genito-urinary fistulas after initial cystourethroscopic survey is completed

Other Options

  • Option A: Intravenous pyelography: This is not the investigation of choice for a VVF now as CT urography is now widely available. The typical appearance of a VVF on an IVP is a cup and saucer appearance. Where CT is not available, IVP can be used.
  • Option B: Voiding cystourethrography: This can be used for VVF but is not preferred as upto 12% of VVF will have a concomitant uretero vaginal fistula which can be missed. 
  • Option D: Positive pressure urethrography: IS for diagnosing urethral diverticula

Educational Objective: 

  • Intravenous contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT – urography) scanning in the excretory phase has become the preferred diagnostic test for genito-urinary fistulas after initial cystourethroscopic survey is completed

Ref: Page 607, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Mixed urinary incontinence
Complex urinary incontinence
Augmented urinary incontinence

questions.text: When the patient’s history suggests an overlap in both stress and urge incontinence symptoms, which of the following terms is used?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mixed urinary incontinence

Explanation

  • Urinary incontinence is defined as involuntary leakage of urine. 
  • Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) is the involuntary leakage of urine with increases in intraabdominal pressure.
  • Urgency urinary incontinence (previously “urge” urinary incontinence) is the involuntary leakage accompanied or immediately preceded by a perceived strong imminent need to void. A related condition, overactive bladder, describes urinary urgency with or without incontinence and usually with increased daytime urinary frequency and nocturia
  • When both stress and urgency symptoms are present, it is called mixed urinary incontinence.

Other Options

  • Option A: Overflow incontinence: Overflow urinary incontinence is the involuntary leakage of urine from an overdistended bladder due to impaired detrusor contractility and/or bladder outlet obstruction. Neurologic diseases such as spinal cord injuries, multiple sclerosis, and diabetes can impair detrusor function. Bladder outlet obstruction can be caused by external compression by abdominal or pelvic masses and pelvic organ prolapse, among other causes.
  • Option C: Complex urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology
  • Option D: Augmented urinary incontinence: There is no such terminology

Educational Objective: 

Types of urinary incontinence:

Ref: Page 541, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition
